For the first 2 I could somewhat get a generalization that the colors were the same but the for checkerboard since it has to do with context I just couldn't put into my brain that those 2 squares were the same. For example if there weren't shadows, or you didn't see the represented pattern of the checkerboard. If you take the shadows first your brain automatically assumes and makes you believe the color underneath the shadow is actually a lighter shade, its one of the reasons we aren't able to comprehend the shade as the same as the darker one. Then thinking about the pattern, our brains when learning things are similar to some computer programs in the sense that they are able to detect patterns and make connections based on those observations. I think its kinda similar to how when we look at something, disregarding the light levels, things look a certain way as they are supposed to, or rather how you've made the connections. Diving deeper into the neurology, the action potential fired when seeing something after recognizing patterns and context takes your previous encounters with things like this hit and so what you see really depends on those factors. This is just my guess based on what I know about these things :)

Wow. This one was mind blowing. I know we have a blind spot in our site on both eyes right in front of us too. There's a test you can do to find it by drawing a black circle on white paper about the size of a quarter and hold it at arms length away from the front of your face. Pick a point in the distance and stare at it. Doing it on your right eye... Hold your black circle in full arm length in front at about eye level. Then move it slowly up a couple inches and to the right a couple inches. It'll be around that area. You'll have to slowly move it around until you see the circle disappear. Don't look directly at the circle because your just moving your blind spot. Keep staring at your stationary object in the distance. It's there I promise. Look it up if you need help finding it.

I think that our eyes work like an HDR photo. We see really well in the dark and we can cope with bright situations so when we look at an object or photo, the shadows and dark spots are brightened and the highlights and bright spots are darkened, this decreases the contrast of our sight and allows us to see the inside of a dark room and through a window with bright sunlight. If we didn't compensate for brightness, in that situation we would either see the outdoors nice and the indoors blacked out or the indoors nice and the outdoors washed out.

It's important to realize that, in the real world, our brain's interpretation of the shades/colors of objects is quite accurate.  So, for example, removing the shadow from the pillar would allow more light to bounce off the B square, making it appear lighter.  Our brains generally present a more accurate vision of the world that you would get from a device measuring the light bouncing off the squares and concluding that A and B are the same shade; in the real world, they wouldn't be.

Sort of - the grass absorbs the red and blue light, but reflects the green light back into your eyes.  The three primary colours of light are red, blue and green (not to be confused with the primary colours of art, red, blue and yellow).  All light is a combination of these colours which, when all put together, create white light.  If something appears white, all the light is reflected.  If something appears black, all the light is absorbed.

it's because of your diaphragm. when you inhale, your diaphragm moves down to increase lung capacity for oxygen intake. the opposite happens when you exhale. hiccups happen when your diaphragm does not move accordingly to this pattern, so your body struggles to go back to the norm. the hiccups happen at unexpected times when your lungs need to take in oxygen but the diaphragm is not doing its job at the correct time.

The only explanation I could come up with is comparison, if we look at the gradient and bar example and split it into 4 parts, A, B, C and D. A being the black end of the gradient and D being the white end, B and C being the ends of the bar, we see B as being lighter compared to A and C being darker compared to B. Our brain reflexively assumes that B is lighter than C. With D gradually changing as it reaches A our brain applies the same effect to the bar, altering our perception of it's colour.

Sunlight is colorless to our eyes even though it is a while light. 
Objects have colors thanks to sunlight and the material object is made of. The material reflects a specific wavelength back to your eyes while it absorbs the rest and the reflected wavelength is the color you see. Yor eyes interpret the wavelength into colors.

Fine I'll answer this question since no one else was able to, basically all clouds are made up of micro-droplets. As further water evaporates and condenses as cloud, the cloud becomes denser, eventually these micro-droplets begin to collide with each other. Micro-droplets are so light that they can float in the air, but as they begin to collide they become heavier, eventually they reach the weight of a typical raindrop, and they fall.

If you spill a glass of water from a balcony, it separates into droplets, because it passes through air that provides resistance.
Your hypothetical "ocean falling from a sky" would be possible if there wasn't any air.
